comments.commentBody:
There were some mighty fine State of the State speeches out there, Ms. Collins, although the stark contrast between Governor Christie and Governor Shumlin was rather refreshing. However, equally entertaining might have been the inclusion of Virginia's outgoing Governor Bob McDonnell's version of mea culpa or Minnesota's Mark Dayton's call for massive public spending as a way to employ people. Still, every governor has an elemental crazy factor in his/her speech as a way to keep people awake waiting for it.

Truth is, no one really listens to those speeches unless there's a hint, a soupçon of scandal, even peripherally, attached to it. State politics are just no fun otherwise.

If Christie's presidential aspirations fail, mebbe HBO can cast him in a new Sopranos-type series. He's already proved his has acting chops.

Just a thought.

http://wifelyperson.blogspot.com/
Our government has decided that civil rights concerns trump the legitimate concerns of crime victims and the societal interest in reducing crime. This is profoundly unfortunate.

I actually think they should be allowed to profile whether the people of interest are or are not religious or share ANY strong religious beliefs.

Such beliefs, regardless of sect are, I believe, pretty fair historical predictors of both terrorism and genocidal behaviour.

It is one kind of motivation to think that something or someone is really wrong. It is an entirely different kind of motivation to think that your god wants you to stop or punish that thing or person.

The history of religious warfare and religious terrorism thoughout the world is something that law enforcement must be aware of and take into account.

Under Obama, old ladies absolutely are searched and checked for explosive residue as often if not more than other passengers.  Thus, the TSA workers meet their "do not hurt people's feelings" quota for the day instead of trying to keep the nation safe.  Profiling of ALL kinds is allowed at border crossings and 30 miles from them.  Let's use that perfectly legal tool to keep the bad guys out of the US.

Come to think of it: if gender cannot be considered, then any investigation of violent crime must start from the premise that the perpetrator could as well be female, not male. That kind of goes with the position that old ladies must be searched at airports at the same rate as young Muslim males.

A wise Supreme Court justice once declared that the Bill of Rights was not a suicide pact. The Obama Justice Department says he was wrong.

Sir, would you mind setting forth the basis for your assertion that "the measured unemployment rate tends to self correct  to 5.5% weather we are in a boom or bust" so that we may evaluate it?  This is contrary to the research by Rogoff and Reinhart in their book "This Time Is Different".  Also, what is the basis that millions of the unemployed are "...getting by with off-the-books jobs"?

@Dryly 41,

It seems rather unlikely that structural unemployment has increased as much as they the numbers indicate. Especially with the Republicans thwarting every possible move to provide support to the unemployed. People will not just go away and starve, they will fight back.

During the last presidential election season many wrote about the effects of individual efforts to live with our dysfunctional economy. This should have involved taking part-time work, or very low paying jobs. But that should not happen if it results in loss of benefits.

The question then is how is it possible for there to be no rioting in the streets, or breadlines, or political heat similar to the 1931~1937 period?

I suspect a major factor might be growth of the underground economy. Which among other things would negate or even reverse the intended purpose of fiscal policy such as tax incentives and welfare payments.

For further reading please see:

America's Underground Economy - http://www.ssc.wisc.edu/econ/archive/wp2011-1.pdf

NOLO - http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/the-underground-economy-unreporte...

US News - http://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/rick-newman/2013/03/18/the-new-undergro...

This does not make the Republican policy any more acceptable. It just means they are hurting the wrong people for the wrong reasons.

There is always the possibility that this is not entirely a new phenomenon. It seems the measured unemployment rate tends to self correct to 5.5% whether we are in a boom or recession.

I suspect this confirms the existence of a robust underground economy. So perhaps in a way the Republicans are partly correct. The long term unemployed and these missing workers are getting by with off-the-books jobs. Where they can work for less than minimum wage, avoid payroll taxes and even the negative tax incentives of getting a legitimate job.

In any case extended unemployment is a necessary counter cyclic incentive and should be extended. It would just be nice to require all those receiving it get skills training or take community service work. Or both.
What an utter fool.  The Israelis are masters of profiling.  If they were not, El Al wouldn't be able to operate an airline.  With proper training, it is very effective.

Many in Congress vote reflexively against any international codes of rights.  There are many international covenants that have been ratified by almost all other civilized countries but not the US.  These members of Congress are afraid of "submitting our citizens to international law". This is taken by the more progressive parts of the world as another part of our country's attitude of superiority.  That attitude is unuseful.

@ Doug Broome
"American schools once led the world. Now they are below the average for rich countries thanks to charlatan politicians."
"Republicans destroyed civilized America with lower taxes."

And what would be better? Mindless, pointless bureaucracies. Of course!
Many of which the Republicans created. "Intelligence" agencies. Education. Regulation.
All strangled by too much money.

Explain That

Look what prop 13 along with a super majority to raise taxes did to California. It almost bankrupted the state and destroyed its tuition free university system. The stupidest thing Obama has done while president is not allowing the Bush tax cuts to expire Now the odds of getting enough revenue to run our country is zero until the next Great Depression.

Politicians who call for higher spending and lower taxes are shams and charlatans.
American schools once led the world. Now they are below the average for rich countries thanks to charlatan politicians.
If Democrats want to restore the US infrastructure and income security and health care, they won't do it with taxes accounting to 15 per cent of gdp compared to the OECD average of 23 per cent.
Republicans destroyed civilized America with lower taxes.

I hope when it's all done, there will be a "Read all replies" immediately after the C-in-C; finding it only after the last reply will be confusing --- you won't realize that there's a chunk of conversation missing till you reach the end.
Odd conclusion, since it is a Senate report, which is, of course, controlled by the dems.

No doubt at least the small nation at least came to terms with the fact of the fundamentally flawed economic system, Fired almost all shyster bankers, most of who are either in prison or awaiting criminal prosecution for long prison sentences. At least it is still a peaceful nation where cops do not wear guns, Murder rate is almost non existence. The government is real representative of the people , unemployment rate is down to below 5%. There is equality in people paying their fair share of taxes, The Government has taken concrete steps to curtail foreclosing of homes and other pit falls of the fundamentally flawed economic system. In the long run the small nation will be fare better off and self sustaining in the long run.

Len,

The effects of solar influences are far-broader than you believe them to be, this is part of the arrogance of the current leadership of the alarm-based movement, better-appreciating the realities of the astronomical influences which matter to climate:

http://wattsupwiththat.com/2012/01/09/scaffeta-on-his-latest-paper-harmo...

Al Rodbell:

Lets see how effective profiling is to stop terrorism:
1) We say anyone who looks like taliban, or Osama Bin Laden or an Imam should be profiled. Seems natural enough. So anyone with a turban must be profiled and targeted irrespective of actually being Muslim. But terrorists aren't fools so they say, when we go to commit an act of terror we will not wear turbans. None of September 11th terrorists, none of the terrorists in the western world have actually worn turbans. Our last terrorist in Boston, looked very not muslim.

2. Now we say, okay anyone who looks like he could be muslim, has a name that is muslim, a country of origin that is muslim, a hairdo or cap that is muslim must be given extra scrutiny. The terrorists are not stupid, so they say, okay we will use people who do not look muslim, who are of American / British origin. The shoe bomber is one of these, the underwear bomber might have been another one of these.

The problem is that for each profile that we have, the profile is not effective in the end. Instead of men, there are women suicide bombers, instead of foreign born terrorists, there are home made ones, instead of brown skinned ones, there are black skinned ones. Instead of Muslim name, there is a western name. Instead of a bomb, there are snipers or there is an American lab made anthrax poison. Could we have predicted the Anthrax murders and terror on the basis of any profile?

We have one group, Arab Muslims, who happen to have reason to resent our invasions, drone attacks and support of one country in region that is often at war with them. They also believe that exercise of the first amendment freedom of speech, even invidious ridicule that is protected under the Constitution, is cause for murder.

This group represents some one percent of this countries population. While no one is suggesting random arrests, focusing surveillance on this group specifically is like mining in an area with known ore deposits.

If this such religious profiling is eliminated, then our investigatory efforts will be diluted to about a tenth of effectiveness, or conversely would require ten fold to prevent the same amount of potential terrorist attacks.

Sometimes reality isn't pretty, but it's still reality.

What is profiling? When a federal agent agent makes a subjective intellectual decision during an investigation to take into account factors prohibited by these rules how will anyone be aware of the reason? It is also interesting that the US Customs Service has openly "profiled" drug smugglers (not based on race or religion) for decades and this method have been supported by the federal courts.

'"profiled" by British security services in London for special scrutiny ... They took me aside and spent hours examining my luggage and interviewing me.'

Were you walking on a sidewalk in London or were you at UK Customs?

In the 1970s, when I was 17 in travelling between Bilbao in Spain and Belfast in Northern Ireland -- both areas plagued by terrorism at the time -- I was "profiled" by British security services in London for special scrutiny because I was a young, single traveller male, with a Catholic surname and red hair.  They took me aside and spent hours examining my luggage and interviewing me.   You know what?   I didn't mind.   I knew that they were just trying to stop the scourge of terrorism, and that I fit the profile of the kind of person they were looking for.  They were polite, firm, and professional.  After they finished (and I missed my flight), they helped me re-book my flight and called my family in Belfast so they wouldn't worry.   In today's dangerous world, these agencies are simply trying to do what is right.  Let's never forget 9/11.

it's clear from the comments that many people have no idea what racial profiling is or what it feels like. this is called privilege.

the rest of us get it. good move.

The IRS routinely audits  organizations throughout the political spectrum claiming tax exempt status.  This is not profiling.  The IRS is not arresting or harassing  individuals based on their race or religion.

Enjoyable puzzle, but as usual, the theme escaped me even with the reveal clue until I read the blog. The waiter clue was the highlight for me as well.

Ah.... the Republican. Ah...Fox Newes. Ah....Bill O'rielly.  Ah...Hannit.y It was an Al Qaeda plot. Planned and executed by Al Qaeda. Had nothing to do with the video nor was it spontaneous. Thank you Senate intelligence Committee Report and thank you New York Times for the facts as best you could get.  To bad the Republicans can not get anything straight nor would they want to.
Some if us old dogs are slower than others. :-)
Nice deflection.  Your comment has absolutely nothing to do with the report from the democratically controlled senate.
You ask:  "Another gun violence tragedy due to negligence"?  Actually, and more accurately:  Another gun violence tragedy due to guns.

NJB,

Zimmerman had his day in court/

How many problems have there been with CCWs compared to the number of CCWS issued? Very small percentage.

The common refrain from the gun zealots is that most shootings are unavoidable and would not have been prevented by gun laws. But the recent movie theatre shooting in Florida over texting of all things shows the lunacy of concealed carry permitting. How many innocent people have to be murdered by frightened or angry armed citizens (or the likes of George Zimmerman who derive their "courage" from packing a gun) abusing the right of self-defense?

It's one thing for these people to have a firearm for home protection. It's quite another to allow them to walk around in public and bring their weapons into public places where they're a potential menace to the rest of us. Almost no other advanced country allows it and we are beyond stupid as a society in thinking that we know better.
Good one, John. I needed a laugh this morning. Of course, you could have substituted "the NYT's method" for "the Harrison method" given the way it spins its reporting.

I'll use the Harrison method of posting unvarnished truth:

Dr. L. Harrison wrote "…. I …. am ….. an …. NRA …. member ….. and …. do … not …. support …. any … firearm … or …. magazine …. restrictions."
Why should anyone take a Nanny Bloomberg front group seriously? He probably thinks more people died from drinking too much diet soda.

I call John the winner of the debate over guns, dogs, and insurance.

QP

John,  Sorry you are wrong here. Although many insurance companies have tried to exclude specific dog breeds from coverage, you will find more and more states that have adopted laws banning insurers from charging more or failing to write policies based on  specific breeds. They may only exclude coverage if the dog has been shown to be dangerous.

Betty van Lew wrote "Just the facts, PLEASE. I beg of you, cite the name of an insurance plan that charges ihigher premiums for dog owners,"

http://www.examiner.com/article/dog-friendly-insurance-companies-the-bat...

With dog bites accounting for one-third of all homeowners insurance liability claims and the average claim costing the insurance company $24,511, insurance companies are passing the $356.2 million bill onto their consumers. Many insurance companies are banning specific breeds all together and dropping those households with a high risk breed.
